Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Development of an Urban-Scale Instrument for Interdisciplinary Research

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) grant will enable the creation of a new tool - The Array of Things - for continuously measuring many aspects of the physical environment of urban areas at the city block scale. Data collected will fill gaps in understanding across many disciplines such as how air pollution is controlled by urban form and traffic patterns, how different materials and surroundings affect the magnitude of the urban heat island, what correlations exist between weather, noise, pollution and traffic and social and behavioral trends, and how urban infrastructure faults and failures can be better detected and predicted. The instrument opens an opportunity to experiment with new sensors and data collection strategies such as will be critical to understanding the urban microbiome or tracking disease outbreaks. Ultimately, the objective is to not only better understand elements of the built and natural infrastructure, but also the interactions of infrastructure systems with people and the environment, to understand complex city dynamics.

The instrument will comprise 500 nodes deployed in the City of Chicago, each with power, Internet, and a base set of sensing and embedded information systems capabilities, with capacity to evolve annually to incorporate new technologies and experiments from an already growing scientific partner community. The project will directly support scientific data infrastructure services for specific communities - engineering, physical, life, social, and climate sciences - with a data repository and tools to support workflows that enable combination with other urban data sources, analytics, and calibration and validation of computational models. In addition, the instrument's open data and application programming interface architectures will support science and education communities incorporating the data into their existing algorithms, tools, and methodologies, to merge the data with their community data resources, and to develop applications that directly access the instrument data in real time. The instrument will provide better spatial and temporal resolution of multiple phenomena simultaneously and at larger scales than what is available from other sensing modalities in urban infrastructure networks. The instrument will be the first instance of a general-purpose research infrastructure that allows researchers to rapidly deploy networks of sensors, embedded systems, computing, and communication systems at scale in urban environments.

This instrument award by the Advanced Cyberinfrastructure Division is jointly supported by the NSF Directorate for Computer & Information Science & Engineering, and the NSF Engineering Directorate (Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems, and Division of Civil, Mechanical & Manufacturing Innovation).

POR.DRECONTENT:
Array of Things (AoT) was originally conceived in 2012 as a new type of urban-scale measurement infrastructure to provide new data for urban sciences, filling in gaps in data such as air quality or micro-climate conditions through greater spatial and temporal resolution.  Like an array telescope that can see deeper using many identical detectors working in concert, AoT would be trained on a city, with many sensor nodes using ?Internet of Things? technologies.  Through multiple workshops involving some 100 scientists from around the world, AoT embraced the need for not only traditional sensing with electronic sensors, but for new types of measurements not previously attempted  Transportation and social science researchers in particular articulated the limitations of manual measurements (e.g., placing counters on roadways) or ad hoc sampling (humans characterizing activities) such as pedestrian flows or interactions among vehicles and pedestrians). 


New Sensor Network Concepts. The experimental instrument proposed in 2015 thus embraced the concept of ?edge computing,? or placing remotely programmable computers within each sensor node to provide (a) analysis of data from high-bandwidth instruments, like cameras, without the concomitant cost of transmission (a critical cost factor with hundreds of devices using commercial wireless networks), and (b) the possibility of user programs running in the nodes to respond to measurements in real-time, avoiding the delays of transmission to a data center. Moreover, the scientific benefits of adding cameras and microphones?originally eschewed due to privacy complexities?was imperative for the instrument to support new questions about human activity and interactions, traffic safety (detecting near misses or phenomena contributing to high crash rates), and many other factors. 

A New Type of Cyberinfrastructure. Today, edge computing and large-scale intelligent sensor networks are common. In 2015, sensor networks comprised simple devices with fixed functionality.  AoT pioneered the integration of edge computing and sensor networks, creating the sensing analog to ?software-defined radio,? or ?software-defined sensors.? Although AoT processors selected in 2015-2017 had limited processing capacity compared to today?s devices, the value was amply demonstrated by enabling scientists to define new measurements long after the devices were manufactured and deployed. For example, no scientist anticipated the value of detecting the percentage of pedestrians wearing face masks, yet this measurement was demonstrated during the 2020 pandemic.


Embedding Policy in Cyberinfrastructure. By adding cameras, the devices would be capable of surveillance and thus the need for strong privacy policies and security to be embedded in the technology and its introduction and operation in the public way.  Here, edge computing added a third class of benefit in that privacy policies regarding the use of images could be embedded in the architecture, for example restricting image processing to the edge (within the sensor node) and discarding rather than saving images once that processing is complete.  Within this policy, images are saved periodically for training image processing software algorithms, but these are protected as though they contain personally identifiable information (they do not), and accessible only to scientists via a data use agreement restricting their use and publication.


New Models for Community Engagement. The vision and support of the City of Chicago, in multiple departments and agencies, in 8 layers of management from electricians to the Mayor, was foundational to the project?s success. AoT instrument pioneered a number of technical and policy approaches necessary for placing experimental instruments in the public way and equally important for partnering with communities.  AoT privacy policies were developed with ethics, privacy, legal, and policy experts from academia, industry, and government?but they also included extensive public engagement through community town-halls done jointly with City of Chicago officials.  The policies underwent a 6-month public comment period and require such comment periods prior to any normative changes in policy.  In addition to transparency, AoT emphasized accountability with an external executive advisory group with leaders from Chicago government, NGOs, industry, and community groups as well as an external review process, leveraging the NSF-funded Center for Applied Cybersecurity Research to review any policy changes or proposed use of training images that might have privacy or ethics considerations.


Challenges. Commercial devices for outdoor applications in 2015 were no open commercial platforms with programmable computers in outdoor conditions (as there are today)?only proprietary systems such as commercial network routers.  Consequently, the project required not only technology development but also enclosure, electrical safety, and mounting designs as well as custom hardware for node fault detection, correction, and recovery.  The resulting complexity of the design that required extensive training and debugging of the manufacturing and assembly processes.  This delayed the project by 9-12 months.  Design changes to the enclosure were also necessary after initial deployments revealed moisture damage as causing premature node failure.  The quality and reliability of power, with frequent power outages, also revealed design improvements that were required to accommodate and recover from spikes and frequent brief outages.
